p: Coronaviruses (CoVs) are enveloped viruses containing a single positive‐stranded RNA, and causing a wide array of respiratory, gastrointestinal, and neurological diseases in human hosts. 1, 2 It has been established that strains of CoVs were at the source of the 2002 severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) and 2012 middle east respiratory syndrome (MERS) epidemics. 3 In late December 2019, a novel CoV of SARS‐CoV‐2 was identified to be the cause of atypical pneumonia outbreak in Wuhan, China, named COVID‐19. 4 The rapidly increasing number of infected patients worldwide prompted the World Health Organization to declare a state of global health emergency to coordinate scientific and medical efforts to rapidly develop a cure for patients. 5 While drug repurposing may be a short‐term and non‐specific solution to treat COVID‐19 patients, 6 development of more targeted inhibitors is highly desirable.
